field_edited_text.value:
xisting Conditions

Industrial and Port Activity: Even
though several former industrial buildings
are being converted to housing, most of
Fells Point’s waterfront is still zoned for
industrial activity. There are four primary
industrial activities in Fells Point: warehous-
ing, maritime services, a concrete batching
plant, and a large chemical plant.

At the extreme western tip of Fells
Point is the Allied Chemical Corp. plant on
Philpot Street. The plant manufactures chro-
mium chemicals and compoufids.

Also located along the western boun-
dary of the area are several metal parts
warehouses and the H &S Bakery.

Around Broadway are several ware-
housing operations, the most notable being
Rukert Terminal Corp., which has operated
in Fells Point for a number of years at the
foot of Broadway and in several historic
warehouses along Thames Street. Also
located adjacent to Broadway are several
ship chandlers who supply goods to ships
for their operations. :

There are two major industrial opera-
tions east of Broadway; one is the Arundel
Corp.’s concrete batching plant on Wolfe
Street, the second is Belt’'s Wharf with two
active warehouses on Fell Street and a ware-
house operation on Aliceanna Street in the
old National Can Company building. Raw
materials at the Arundel Corp., which are
delivered by barge, are mixed to form con-
crete which is then trucked to construction
sites in the region.

In the Canton area, along Boston Street
at Lakewood, is a cluster of large industrial
and warehouse buildings including the old
J. S. Young factory, now vacant expect for
warehousing in several large buildings; R.
Renneburg and Sons, manufacturer of steel
machine products; two large warehouses
between Boston Street and the harbor; and
the American Can Co. plant covering sev-
eral city blocks on the northside of Boston
Street at O’Donnell Street.

Towing companies on Boston Street
and at the Recreation Pier, are the major
maritime businesses now along the Fells
Point shoreline. The City Pier at the foot of
Broadway is also occasionally used as a
temporary mooring for cargo ships waiting
assignment to a pier in another part of the
harbor. The City’s Marine Police Unit was
located for many years at Broadway Pier in
Fells Point. The unit has now moved to Pier
6 in the Inner Harbor, in temporary
facilities.

At the eastern end of Boston Street is
NBC Lines where containers are consoli-
dated from other ports and distributed to



Maritime activities, tugs at the Recreation Pier

larger ships for shipment or inland
destinations.

Commercial Activity: Fells Point pro-
vides a diverse mix of commercial activity.
Associated with the area’s towing compan-
ies are ship chandlers who supply provisions
and services to ships docking in the Balti-
more harbor. Along Broadway, the area’s
commercial spine, there are hardware
stores, banks, secondhand and specialty
shops, antique stores, and restaurants. And,
there are the taverns. Fells Point contains
one of the highest concentrations of tav-
erns of any community in the City. The bars
attract an interesting clientele of visiting sail-
ors, young singles, local residents, and tour-
ists. Fells Point’s open stall Broadway
Market also draws customers from the en-
tire region. This mix of commercial activity
is considered one of Fells Point’s major
assets.

Residential Areas: There has been a
strong residential community in Fells Point
since the founding in the early 18th cen-
tury. Originally houses were built in Fells
Point for those who worked nearby in the
port and in related maritime businesses.
During the 19th century, Fells Point became
the home of thousands of Eastern European
immigrants many of whose descendents still
live in the area.

During the 1960s a trickle of new resi-
dents, many artists and “urban pioneers,”
discovered Fells Point. As the appeal of liv-
ing in an historic community adjacent to the
harbor grew, increasing numbers of people

began to move into the community to ren-
ovate its 19th-century brick rowhouses. To-
day, the market for housing in Fells Point
has advanced to the point that developers
have proposed converting many of the
area’s abandoned warehouses to condo-
miniums and apartments and constructing
new townhouses on vacant land.

Recreation Areas: To provide a focal
point for the community, the City invested
more than $1 million to construct a brick-
paved plaza in the bed of South Broadway
between Lancaster and Thames Streets. The
plaza is used for community events and fes-
tivals as well as a place to watch the bustling
activity which is a day-to-day occurrence in
Fells Point. The City has also constructed a
neighborhood park with a play area for
small children, green space, and gazebo at
the corner of Thames and Wolfe Streets.
Besides these new facilities, the Recreation
Pier with a second-story outdoor basketball
court and its indoor game room has long
been a valuable resource for the Fells Point
community. In 1984 the Chester Street Park
and Promenade was completed.

In the Canton area there is a small
recreation center with courts and play
equipment and several playfields at East
and Ellwood Streets. The City has also con-
structed a public pier at Boston and Lake-
wood Streets.





2
